Chapter 4 LAGOS Analysis 4.1 Loading in data

Chapter 4 LAGOS Analysis 4.1 Loading in data 4.1.1 First download and then specifically grab the locus (or site lat longs) # #Lagos download script LAGOSNE::lagosne_get(dest_folder = LAGOSNE:::lagos_path()) ## Warning in LAGOSNE::lagosne_get(dest_folder = LAGOSNE:::lagos_path()): LAGOSNE data for this version already exists on the local machine. ## Re-download if neccessary using the 'overwrite` argument.' #Load in lagos lagos <- lagosne_load() ## Warning in (function (version = NULL, fpath = NA) : LAGOSNE version unspecified, ## loading version: 1.087.3 #Grab the lake centroid info lake_centers <- lagos$locus 4.1.2 Convert to spatial data spatial_lakes <- st_as_sf(lake_centers,coords=c('nhd_long','nhd_lat'), crs=4326) %>% st_transform(2163) subset_spatial <- spatial_lakes %>% slice(1:100) subset_baser <- spatial_lakes[1:100,] #Dynamic mapviewer mapview(subset_spatial) 4.1.3 Subset to only Minnesota states <- us_states() #Plot all the states to check if they loaded #mapview(states) minnesota <- states %>% filter(name == 'Minnesota') %>% st_transform(2163) #Subset lakes based on spatial position minnesota_lakes <- spatial_lakes[minnesota,] #Plotting the first 1000 lakes minnesota_lakes %>% arrange(-lake_area_ha) %>% slice(1:1000) %>% mapview(.,zcol = 'lake_area_ha')

Chapter 5 In-Class work 5.1 1) Show a map outline of Iowa and Illinois (similar to Minnesota map upstream) 5.2 2) Subset LAGOS data to these sites, how many sites are in Illinois and Iowa 5.3 3) What is the distribution of lake size in Iowa vs. Minnesota? 5.4 4) Make an interactive plot of lakes in Iowa and Illinois and color them 5.5 5) What other data sources might we use to understand how reservoirs and

Chapter 5 In-Class work 5.1 1) Show a map outline of Iowa and Illinois (similar to Minnesota map upstream) #Iowa and Illinois Lakes spatial_lakes <- st_as_sf(lake_centers,coords=c('nhd_long','nhd_lat'), crs=4326) %>% st_transform(2163) subset_spatial <- spatial_lakes %>% slice(1:100) subset_baser <- spatial_lakes[1:100,] states <- us_states() iowa_il <- states %>% filter(name %in% c('Iowa', 'Illinois')) %>% st_transform(2163) mapview(iowa_il) 5.2 2) Subset LAGOS data to these sites, how many sites are in Illinois and Iowa combined? How does this compare to Minnesota? IA + IL sites = 16,466 obs of 17 variables MN sites = 29,038 obs of 17 variables If we are comparing data sites, Minnesota has more than Illinois and Iowa combined. #subset using LAGOS data iowa_il_lakes <- spatial_lakes[iowa_il,] 5.3 3) What is the distribution of lake size in Iowa vs. Minnesota? Here I want to see a histogram plot with lake size on x-axis and frequency on y axis (check out geom_histogram) #Iowa lakes spatial_lakes <- st_as_sf(lake_centers,coords=c('nhd_long','nhd_lat'), crs=4326) %>% st_transform(2163) subset_spatial <- spatial_lakes %>% slice(1:100) subset_baser <- spatial_lakes[1:100,] states <- us_states() iowa<- states %>% filter(name == "Iowa") %>% st_transform(2163) iowa_lakes <- spatial_lakes[iowa,] #Minnesota Lakes minnesota <- states %>% filter(name == 'Minnesota') %>% st_transform(2163) minnesota_lakes <- spatial_lakes[minnesota,] iowa_MN <- states %>% filter(name %in% c('Iowa', 'Minnesota')) %>% st_transform(2163) IA_MN_lakes <- spatial_lakes %>% .[iowa_MN,] %>% st_join(iowa_MN) #IA vs MN Lake Area Histogram ggplot() + geom_histogram(filter(IA_MN_lakes, name == "Minnesota"), mapping = aes(lake_area_ha), bins= 15, color="darkblue", fill="lightblue")+ scale_x_log10() + labs(title= "Iowa vs Minnesota Lake Size", x= "Lake Area (ha)", y= 'Frequency') + geom_histogram(filter(IA_MN_lakes, name == "Iowa"), mapping = aes(lake_area_ha), bins = 15, color="red", fill="pink")+ scale_x_log10() + labs(title="Iowa vs Minnesota Lake Size", x="Lake Area(ha)", y='Frequency')+ facet_wrap(~name) ## Scale for 'x' is already present. Adding another scale for 'x', which will ## replace the existing scale. 5.4 4) Make an interactive plot of lakes in Iowa and Illinois and color them by lake area in hectares iowa_il_lakes %>% arrange(-lake_area_ha) %>% slice(1:1000) %>% mapview(.,zcol = 'lake_area_ha') 5.5 5) What other data sources might we use to understand how reservoirs and natural lakes vary in size in these three states? There could be copious accounts of scientific research that would help us understand how lakes vary in size throughout Minnesota, Iowa, and Illinois. Climate and ecological data surrounding these lakes would allow for further analysis of possible patterns and differences from state to state. The following research was conducted by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency as a report for the EPAs 2007 National Lake Assessment National Lake Assessment
